WorkItem.Description:
From thread:
http://phpexcel.codeplex.com/Thread/View.aspx?ThreadId=56663
 
----
So I downloaded the latest stable and the latest SVN versions, which show the same signs of... let's say "strangeness".
 
See, I edit my code in Eclipse and as soon as I loaded the library, the IDE jumped at my throat with those red Xs that hurt the eyes. I investigated the matter and found what is obviously Java code in the middle of the JAMA directories. After a little research my guess is the files in question are an adaptation of the original JAMA Java package, and quite possibly a work in progress. As I may never include said files (my downloading the latest files was just to correct a value type issue I had with Excel5), can I assume it is safe to comment this code out ?
 
Thanks in advance.

Comments.Message: Think this can be safely removed.
I've made some changes to the JAMA classes as part of my overhaul of the calculation engine, so I'll ensure that the Java code is either converted to PHP or removed
Core JAMA classes upgraded to PHP5, and remaining Java code converted to PHP

Hi Mark, I think the posters were really referring to some of the example files in the Classes/PHPExcel/Shared/JAMA/examples/ folder. Here is a screenshot of errors/warnings in Eclipse:

http://img32.imageshack.us/img32/5418/phpmbxampphtdocsphpexce.png

>> I think the posters were really referring to some of the example files in the Classes/PHPExcel/Shared/JAMA/examples/ folder. 
Perhaps. 
I did find some java code in the core scripts while I was converting them, fortunately those blocks didn't actually trigger any PHP errors. But I didn't particularly check any of the example or documentation files for JAMA. Of course, it was originally a java package ported to PHP: the original porters obviously didn't convert it all
